title: Jnana Karma Sanyasa Yoga
subtitle: The Yoga of Knowledge and Renunciation of Action
summary: In this chapter, Krishna reveals the ancient nature of the yoga of knowledge and action, explaining how wisdom (jnana) burns away all karma. He describes the proper performance of action, the importance of sacrifice (yajna), and the qualities of a true sage. The chapter culminates in the famous verse urging Arjuna to arm himself with wisdom (4.42).

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम् | विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत् ||
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca | imaṃ vivasvate yogaṃ proktavān aham avyayam | vivasvān manave prāha manur ikṣvākave 'bravīt ||
verses.translation: The Blessed Lord said: I taught this imperishable yoga to Vivasvan (the sun-god); Vivasvan taught it to Manu (his son); Manu taught it to Ikshvaku.
verses.explanation: Krishna establishes the antiquity of the Gita's teachings, tracing their lineage from himself through the sun-god to ancient kings, showing this wisdom is eternal (sanatana).

verses.sanskrit: एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः | स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप ||
verses.transliteration: evaṃ paramparā-prāptam imaṃ rājarṣayo viduḥ | sa kāleneha mahatā yogo naṣṭaḥ parantapa ||
verses.translation: Thus received in succession, the royal sages knew this yoga. But over great time, O scorcher of foes, this yoga was lost in the world.
verses.explanation: Krishna explains how this knowledge was preserved by enlightened kings (rajarishis) but became obscured over time due to lack of practice.

verses.sanskrit: स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः | भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम् ||
verses.transliteration: sa evāyaṃ mayā te 'dya yogaḥ proktaḥ purātanaḥ | bhakto 'si me sakhā ceti rahasyaṃ hy etad uttamam ||
verses.translation: That same ancient yoga has today been told to you by Me, for you are My devotee and friend. This is the supreme secret.
verses.explanation: Krishna reveals he is imparting this secret wisdom to Arjuna because of their special relationship—as both devotee and friend.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः | कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति ||
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca | aparaṃ bhavato janma paraṃ janma vivasvataḥ | katham etad vijānīyāṃ tvam ādau proktavān iti ||
verses.translation: Arjuna said: Later was Your birth, earlier was the birth of Vivasvan (the sun-god). How then am I to understand that You taught this yoga in the beginning?
verses.explanation: Arjuna expresses confusion about Krishna's claim to have taught this yoga in ancient times, given Krishna's apparent recent birth.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन | तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप ||
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca | bahūni me vyatītāni janmāni tava cārjuna | tāny ahaṃ veda sarvāṇi na tvaṃ vettha parantapa ||
verses.translation: The Blessed Lord said: Many births of Mine have passed, as well as of yours, O Arjuna. I remember them all, but you do not, O scorcher of foes.
verses.explanation: Krishna reveals his divine nature—while ordinary beings forget past lives, he remembers all his incarnations.

verses.sanskrit: अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन् | प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय संभवाम्यात्ममायया ||
verses.transliteration: ajo 'pi sann avyayātmā bhūtānām īśvaro 'pi san | prakṛtiṃ svām adhiṣṭhāya sambhavāmy ātma-māyayā ||
verses.translation: Though I am unborn and inexhaustible in essence, though I am the Lord of all beings, yet by controlling My material nature, I appear by My own power (maya).
verses.explanation: Krishna explains his transcendental nature—though eternal and unchanging, he manifests through his divine energy (maya) to uphold dharma.

verses.sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत | अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम् ||
verses.transliteration: yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānir bhavati bhārata | abhyutthānam adharmasya tadātmānaṃ sṛjāmy aham ||
verses.translation: Whenever there is decline of righteousness, O Bharata, and rise of unrighteousness, then I manifest Myself.
verses.explanation: This famous verse establishes Krishna's role as the divine protector of dharma who incarnates whenever spiritual values decline.

verses.sanskrit: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम् | धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे ||
verses.transliteration: paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṃ vināśāya ca duṣkṛtām | dharma-saṃsthāpanārthāya sambhavāmi yuge yuge ||
verses.translation: For the protection of the good, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of righteousness, I manifest age after age.
verses.explanation: Krishna describes the threefold purpose of divine incarnations: to protect devotees, annihilate evil, and reestablish cosmic order.

verses.sanskrit: जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः | त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन ||
verses.transliteration: janma karma ca me divyam evaṃ yo vetti tattvataḥ | tyaktvā dehaṃ punar janma naiti mām eti so 'rjuna ||
verses.translation: One who knows in truth My divine birth and activities, upon leaving the body, does not take birth again but comes to Me, O Arjuna.
verses.explanation: Understanding Krishna's divine nature and purpose leads to liberation from rebirth.

verses.sanskrit: वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः | बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः ||
verses.transliteration: vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhā man-mayā mām upāśritāḥ | bahavo jñāna-tapasā pūtā mad-bhāvam āgatāḥ ||
verses.translation: Freed from attachment, fear, and anger, absorbed in Me, taking refuge in Me, purified by the fire of knowledge, many have attained My being.
verses.explanation: Krishna describes the qualities of those who attain him: detachment, devotion, and wisdom-purified consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम् | मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः ||
verses.transliteration: ye yathā māṃ prapadyante tāṃs tathaiva bhajāmy aham | mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ ||
verses.translation: As men approach Me, so I receive them. All paths, O Partha, lead to Me.
verses.explanation: Krishna declares his impartiality—he reciprocates with devotees according to their level of surrender, accepting all genuine spiritual approaches.

verses.sanskrit: काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः | क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा ||
verses.transliteration: kāṅkṣantaḥ karmaṇāṃ siddhiṃ yajanta iha devatāḥ | kṣipraṃ hi mānuṣe loke siddhir bhavati karmajā ||
verses.translation: Those who desire success in actions worship the gods here (in this world), for in the human world, success from action comes quickly.
verses.explanation: Krishna acknowledges conventional worship for material gains but will soon contrast this with higher wisdom.

verses.sanskrit: चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः | तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम् ||
verses.transliteration: cātur-varṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇa-karma-vibhāgaśaḥ | tasya kartāram api māṃ viddhy akartāram avyayam ||
verses.translation: The four varnas (orders of society) were created by Me according to divisions of qualities and duties. Though I am their creator, know Me to be the non-doer and imperishable.
verses.explanation: Krishna explains the varna system is based on innate nature (guna) and work (karma), not birth, while maintaining his transcendental position beyond all action.

verses.sanskrit: न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा | इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते ||
verses.transliteration: na māṃ karmāṇi limpanti na me karma-phale spṛhā | iti māṃ yo 'bhijānāti karmabhir na sa badhyate ||
verses.translation: Actions do not taint Me, nor do I desire their fruits. One who understands Me thus is not bound by actions.
verses.explanation: Krishna's actions are motiveless and perfect; those who realize this transcend karmic bondage.

verses.sanskrit: एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः | कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम् ||
verses.transliteration: evaṃ jñātvā kṛtaṃ karma pūrvair api mumukṣubhiḥ | kuru karmaiva tasmāt tvaṃ pūrvaiḥ pūrvataraṃ kṛtam ||
verses.translation: Knowing thus, the ancient seekers of liberation performed action. Therefore, you too should perform action as the ancients did.
verses.explanation: Krishna urges Arjuna to follow the example of enlightened beings who acted with wisdom.

verses.sanskrit: किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः | तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् ||
verses.transliteration: kiṃ karma kim akarmeti kavayo 'py atra mohitāḥ | tat te karma pravakṣyāmi yaj jñātvā mokṣyase 'śubhāt ||
verses.translation: What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused about this. I shall explain what action is, knowing which you shall be free from evil.
verses.explanation: Krishna prepares to reveal the subtle distinction between action, inaction, and forbidden action—a profound spiritual insight.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः | अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः ||
verses.transliteration: karmaṇo hy api boddhavyaṃ boddhavyaṃ ca vikarmaṇaḥ | akarmaṇaś ca boddhavyaṃ gahanā karmaṇo gatiḥ ||
verses.translation: One must understand the nature of action, the nature of wrong action, and the nature of inaction. The path of action is profound.
verses.explanation: True wisdom requires discerning proper action (karma), improper action (vikarma), and transcendental inaction (akarma) within apparent action.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः | स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत् ||
verses.transliteration: karmaṇy akarma yaḥ paśyed akarmaṇi ca karma yaḥ | sa buddhimān manuṣyeṣu sa yuktaḥ kṛtsna-karma-kṛt ||
verses.translation: He who sees inaction in action and action in inaction—he is wise among men, he is engaged in yoga while performing all actions.
verses.explanation: The enlightened perceive the soul's inactivity amidst bodily action and recognize the active cultivation of spiritual consciousness as true 'action'.

verses.sanskrit: यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः | ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः ||
verses.transliteration: yasya sarve samārambhāḥ kāma-saṅkalpa-varjitāḥ | jñānāgni-dagdha-karmāṇaṃ tam āhuḥ paṇḍitaṃ budhāḥ ||
verses.translation: One whose undertakings are all free from selfish desires and motives, whose actions are burned by the fire of wisdom—him the wise call a sage.
verses.explanation: The true scholar (pandita) acts without egoistic motives; their karma is 'burned' by spiritual knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः | कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः ||
verses.transliteration: tyaktvā karma-phalāsaṅgaṃ nitya-tṛpto nirāśrayaḥ | karmaṇy abhipravṛtto 'pi naiva kiñcit karoti saḥ ||
verses.translation: Having abandoned attachment to the fruits of action, ever content, dependent on nothing, though engaged in action, he does nothing at all.
verses.explanation: The liberated soul acts without attachment, like a lotus leaf untouched by water, remaining free from karmic entanglement.

verses.sanskrit: निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः | शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम् ||
verses.transliteration: nirāśīr yata-cittātmā tyakta-sarva-parigrahaḥ | śārīraṃ kevalaṃ karma kurvann āpnoti kilbiṣam ||
verses.translation: Free from expectations, with mind and self controlled, having abandoned all possessions, performing mere bodily action, he incurs no sin.
verses.explanation: The sage acts only to sustain the body, without possessiveness or expectation, thus remaining pure.

verses.sanskrit: यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः | समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते ||
verses.transliteration: yadṛcchā-lābha-santuṣṭo dvandvātīto vimatsaraḥ | samaḥ siddhāv asiddhau ca kṛtvāpi na nibadhyate ||
verses.translation: Content with whatever comes by chance, beyond dualities, free from envy, equipoised in success and failure—though acting, he is not bound.
verses.explanation: The yogi maintains equilibrium, unaffected by life's ups and downs, thus transcending karma.

verses.sanskrit: गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः | यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते ||
verses.transliteration: gata-saṅgasya muktasya jñānāvasthita-cetasaḥ | yajñāyācarataḥ karma samagraṃ pravilīyate ||
verses.translation: For one who is unattached, liberated, with mind fixed in knowledge, who acts as a sacrifice—all work dissolves entirely (in Brahman).
verses.explanation: Actions performed as offerings (yajna) with spiritual understanding merge into the infinite, leaving no residue.

verses.sanskrit: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम् | ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना ||
verses.transliteration: brahmārpaṇaṃ brahma havir brahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam | brahmaiva tena gantavyaṃ brahma-karma-samādhinā ||
verses.translation: The offering is Brahman, the oblation is Brahman, poured by Brahman into the fire of Brahman. Brahman alone is to be attained by him who sees Brahman in action.
verses.explanation: The highest vision sees the divine in all aspects of ritual—the offerer, offering, and process—leading to union with the Absolute.

verses.sanskrit: दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते | ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति ||
verses.transliteration: daivam evāpare yajñaṃ yoginaḥ paryupāsate | brahmāgnāv apare yajñaṃ yajñenaivopajuhvati ||
verses.translation: Some yogis perform sacrifice to the gods alone, while others offer sacrifice by the sacrifice itself into the fire of Brahman.
verses.explanation: Krishna describes different levels of spiritual practice—worship of deities or direct realization of the Supreme.

verses.sanskrit: श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति | शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति ||
verses.transliteration: śrotrādīnīndriyāṇy anye saṃyamāgniṣu juhvati | śabdādīn viṣayān anya indriyāgniṣu juhvati ||
verses.translation: Some offer hearing and other senses into the fires of restraint; others offer sound and other objects into the fires of the senses.
verses.explanation: Advanced practitioners 'sacrifice' sense perceptions through self-control, while others offer sensory experiences as spiritual practice.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे | आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते ||
verses.transliteration: sarvāṇīndriya-karmāṇi prāṇa-karmāṇi cāpare | ātma-saṃyama-yogāgnau juhvati jñāna-dīpite ||
verses.translation: Others sacrifice all functions of the senses and vital forces into the fire of self-control, kindled by knowledge.
verses.explanation: The highest yogis renounce all bodily and mental activities through wisdom-fueled discipline.

verses.sanskrit: द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे | स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतयः संशितव्रताः ||
verses.transliteration: dravya-yajñās tapo-yajñā yoga-yajñās tathāpare | svādhyāya-jñāna-yajñāś ca yatayaḥ saṃśita-vratāḥ ||
verses.translation: Some offer material possessions, austerities, or yoga practice as sacrifice, while ascetics of strict vows offer study of scriptures and wisdom as sacrifice.
verses.explanation: Krishna enumerates various forms of spiritual offering—material, ascetic, meditative, and intellectual.

verses.sanskrit: अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे | प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः ||
verses.transliteration: apāne juhvati prāṇaṃ prāṇe 'pānaṃ tathāpare | prāṇāpāna-gatī ruddhvā prāṇāyāma-parāyaṇāḥ ||
verses.translation: Others offer the incoming breath (prana) into the outgoing breath (apana), and the outgoing into the incoming, restraining the flow of prana and apana, absorbed in breath control.
verses.explanation: Describes pranayama (yogic breathing) as a form of inner sacrifice where vital energies are harmonized.

verses.sanskrit: अपरे नियताहाराः प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति | सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः ||
verses.transliteration: apare niyatāhārāḥ prāṇān prāṇeṣu juhvati | sarve 'py ete yajña-vido yajña-kṣapita-kalmaṣāḥ ||
verses.translation: Others, regulating their food, offer the vital forces into the vital forces. All these are knowers of sacrifice, whose sins are destroyed by sacrifice.
verses.explanation: Even controlled eating can be spiritual practice when offered with sacred intention, purifying the practitioner.

verses.sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम् | नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम ||
verses.transliteration: yajña-śiṣṭāmṛta-bhujo yānti brahma sanātanam | nāyaṃ loko 'sty ayajñasya kuto 'nyaḥ kuru-sattama ||
verses.translation: Those who partake of the nectar of sacrifice's remnants go to the eternal Brahman. This world is not for the non-sacrificer; how then the next, O best of Kurus?
verses.explanation: Sacrificial offerings sanctify life; those who live without this sacred attitude miss both material and spiritual prosperity.

verses.sanskrit: एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे | कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे ||
verses.transliteration: evaṃ bahu-vidhā yajñā vitatā brahmaṇo mukhe | karma-jān viddhi tān sarvān evaṃ jñātvā vimokṣyase ||
verses.translation: Thus, various sacrifices are spread before Brahman (the Vedas). Know them all as born of action. Knowing thus, you shall be liberated.
verses.explanation: All Vedic rituals ultimately aim at spiritual freedom when performed with understanding.

verses.sanskrit: श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप | सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते ||
verses.transliteration: śreyān dravya-mayād yajñāj jñāna-yajñaḥ parantapa | sarvaṃ karmākhilaṃ pārtha jñāne parisamāpyate ||
verses.translation: Superior to material sacrifices is the sacrifice of knowledge, O scorcher of foes. All actions, O Partha, culminate in knowledge.
verses.explanation: While material rituals have value, wisdom (jnana) is the highest 'sacrifice' that completes all spiritual practice.

verses.sanskrit: तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया | उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः ||
verses.transliteration: tad viddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā | upadekṣyanti te jñānaṃ jñāninas tattva-darśinaḥ ||
verses.translation: Know that by prostrations, by questioning, and by service. The wise who have realized the truth will impart knowledge to you.
verses.explanation: Krishna prescribes the threefold method to acquire wisdom: surrender, sincere inquiry, and service to enlightened teachers.

verses.sanskrit: यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव | येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि ||
verses.transliteration: yaj jñātvā na punar moham evaṃ yāsyasi pāṇḍava | yena bhūtāny aśeṣeṇa drakṣyasy ātmany atho mayi ||
verses.translation: Knowing that, O Pandava, you shall not again be deluded thus. By that knowledge, you shall see all beings without exception in the Self, and then in Me.
verses.explanation: True wisdom dispels illusion, revealing the unity of all existence in the Self and ultimately in Krishna.

verses.sanskrit: अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः | सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि ||
verses.transliteration: api ced asi pāpebhyaḥ sarvebhyaḥ pāpa-kṛt-tamaḥ | sarvaṃ jñāna-plavenaiva vṛjinaṃ santariṣyasi ||
verses.translation: Even if you are the worst of sinners, you shall cross beyond all sin by the boat of knowledge.
verses.explanation: Divine knowledge has the power to purify even the gravest sins, like a raft carrying one across worldly misery.

verses.sanskrit: यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन | ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा ||
verses.transliteration: yathaidhāṃsi samiddho 'gnir bhasma-sāt kurute 'rjuna | jñānāgniḥ sarva-karmāṇi bhasma-sāt kurute tathā ||
verses.translation: As blazing fire reduces wood to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all karma to ashes.
verses.explanation: Wisdom burns away karmic bonds just as fire consumes fuel—one of the Gita's most powerful metaphors for liberation.

verses.sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते | तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति ||
verses.transliteration: na hi jñānena sadṛśaṃ pavitram iha vidyate | tat svayaṃ yoga-saṃsiddhaḥ kālenātmani vindati ||
verses.translation: There is indeed nothing purifying like knowledge in this world. He who is perfected in yoga finds this in the Self in due time.
verses.explanation: Knowledge is the supreme purifier, naturally revealed to advanced practitioners through disciplined practice.

verses.sanskrit: श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः | ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति ||
verses.transliteration: śraddhāvāṃl labhate jñānaṃ tat-paraḥ saṃyatendriyaḥ | jñānaṃ labdhvā parāṃ śāntim acireṇādhigacchati ||
verses.translation: The faithful, devoted to it and mastering the senses, attains knowledge. Having attained knowledge, he quickly reaches supreme peace.
verses.explanation: Krishna outlines the process: faith → dedication → sense control → knowledge → ultimate peace.

verses.sanskrit: अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति | नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः ||
verses.transliteration: ajñaś cāśraddadhānaś ca saṃśayātmā vinaśyati | nāyaṃ loko 'sti na paro na sukhaṃ saṃśayātmanaḥ ||
verses.translation: The ignorant, the faithless, the doubting self perishes. For the doubting soul, there is neither this world nor the next, nor happiness.
verses.explanation: Doubt and lack of faith destroy spiritual progress, leaving one stranded in existential misery.

verses.sanskrit: योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसञ्छिन्नसंशयम् | आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय ||
verses.transliteration: yoga-sannyasta-karmāṇaṃ jñāna-sañchinna-saṃśayam | ātmavantaṃ na karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya ||
verses.translation: One who has renounced actions through yoga, whose doubts are severed by knowledge, who is self-possessed—actions do not bind him, O Dhananjaya.
verses.explanation: The enlightened, having cut through doubt with wisdom, act without karmic consequences.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मादज्ञानसम्भूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः | छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत ||
verses.transliteration: tasmād ajñāna-sambhūtaṃ hṛt-sthaṃ jñānāsinātmanaḥ | chittvainaṃ saṃśayaṃ yogam ātiṣṭhottiṣṭha bhārata ||
verses.translation: Therefore, with the sword of knowledge, cut asunder this doubt in your heart born of ignorance. Take refuge in yoga. Arise, O Bharata!
verses.explanation: Krishna's climactic exhortation: Arm yourself with wisdom to destroy doubt, embrace yoga, and fulfill your duty!
